Concepts of Revisioning

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe policy revisioning and EffDated
entities

¢ Describe window mode and slice mode

« Access a policy in window and slice mode
using Gosu

i EffDated entities

Are created to track the state of an entity over effective time

* Have EffectiveDate and ExpirationDate columns

« Are members of an effective dated graph, rooted at an effdatedbranch entity.

PersonalVehicle (pc_personalvehicle) (delegates to Modifiable, Coverable,

> Description
Fields

EffectiveDate datetime (wis

Effective date of this row or FNULL in the database if equal to the period start

ExpirationDate «
Expired date of this row: or of NULL Ms inthe ‘database if equal to the period end

i PolicyPeriod entity G

¢ PolicyPeriod entity is:

* the root of all EffDated entities on a policy graph

+ not EffDated, but type of effDatedBranch
¢ Set relationship between an EffDated entity and PolicyPeriod

* effDatedBranchType="PolicyPeriod" in the eti file

(=) PersonalVehicle.eti
?xml version="1.0"?>

<entity

xmlins="http: //guidewire.com/datamodel"
desc="Personal Vehicle"

displayName="Personal Vehicle"

leffDatedBranchType="PolicyPeriod"|

entity="PersonalVehicle"

2
3
4
6

i EffDated entity columns

EffectiveDate and ExpirationDate

* null value means this entity has same effective and expiration dates as its root (i.e.
PolicyPeriod.PeriodStart and PolicyPeriod.PeriodEnd)

Fixedid — a unique identifier that PolicyCenter generates when a new object is
created

* Cannot be null
* Stays same for all version of the object
Branch -— link to the associated PolicyPeriod
* Cannot be null
BasedOn — a pointer back to prior version of this entity
¢ If this is the first version, BasedOn is null
* Column on EffDated entity as well as the PolicyPeriod

i Creating an EffDated entity Ga

¢ First, identify the root entity of type EffDatedBranch, such as PolicyPeriod
« Next, create the EffDated entity

* Set the entity attributes
+ type="EffDated”
+ effDatedBranchType="PolicyPeriod*

¢ Follow other rules relevant to the entity (e.g., PolicyLine or Coverage entities have their own
specific rules)

¢ Refer to the existing EffDated entities as examples

« For example, PersonalVehicle.eti, PersonalAutoCov.eti, BOPBuilding.eti, etc.

i BasedOn example Gi

Driver and PersonalVehicle EffDated entities have BasedOn properties

Mar Dec
Submission on Mar 1 (Eff Mar 1 — Dec 31) 1
policy with 1 car and 1 driver i |__|
DriverV1.BasedOn = null id
PersonalVehicleV1.BasedOn = null CG)
2
Policy Change 1 on Mar 2 (Eff Apr 1 - Dec 31) es
change car 1, no change in driver ns
DriverV2.BasedOn = DriverV1 CG)
PersonalVehicleV2.BasedOn = PersonalVehicleV1
3
Policy Change 2 on Mar 3 — (Eff May 1 - Dec 31) |

change car 1, no change in driver
DriverV3.BasedOn = DriverV2

id
PersonalVehicleV3.BasedOn = PersonalVehicleV2 | Historical PolicyPeriod
Enforced PolicyPeriod

Structure of revisioning across effective
time

i PolicyPeriod G

A PolicyPeriod is one "version" of the policy

* Has effective and expiration dates (PeriodStart and PeriodEnd) which define the actual term of

the policy
¢ Has an EditEffectiveDate, which is the date at which changes from a job are applied
policy second teen driver renewal
created auto added added (premium changed)
04/20/08 07/20/08 10/20/08 04/20/09
J $270 { $450 J $920 J $990

= Ss= 3e=_2)
1 2 3

3 PolicyPeriods and 1 PolicyPeriod and
1 PolicyTerm: 1 PolicyTerm:
04/20/08 — 04/20/09 04/20/09 — 04/20/10

i Model time and effective time Gi
To track policy changes over time, a policy must be considered in two different time
dimensions:

¢ Model time is the actual real-world time when policies are created or jobs are
bound

* Effective time is the time dimension of the policy itself within the policy period

i Example

Effective time

—-

Jan1

Model time

Enforced PolicyPeriod

Mar

Dec 31

Mar 1 — policy with 1 car
effective Apr 1 - Dec 31
Model date: Mar 1
Effective date: Apr 1

Mar 2 - add car 2
effective May 1 - Dec 31
Model date: Mar 2
Effective date: May 1

Mar 3 — Remove car 2
effective May 1 - Dec 31
Model date: Mar 3
Effective date: May 1

i Sub-objects across effective time (1) Ga

¢ Every policy revision is the root of a complex graph of sub-objects such as drivers,
vehicles, coverages, and so on

* If one of these objects changes then that object has its own effective and expiration date

* Consider an example, where a personal auto submission is created with one

vehicle
ub-object: Vehicle,
Mar 1 Dec 31 PersonalVehicle
Color: RED

9} = EffectiveDate: null

ExpirationDate: null
Fixedld: 12345

Submission

i Sub-objects across effective time (2) Ga

* On Sep 1, the customer calls and says the car was painted blue today

« Anew policy revision is created by cloning a new row in the database differing in
effective date and expiration date

¢ Expiration date of first row is the effective date of second row
¢ Arowis effective at a date specified if:

¢ Effective date <= specified date < expiration date

i Sub-objects across effective time (3)

ub-object: Vehicle
Color: RED
EffectiveDate: null
Mar 1 Dec 31 /{ ExpirationDate: null
a ——s Fixedld: 12345

Submission

PersonalVehicle

Color: RED
| EffectiveDate: null
xpirationDate: Sept 1
Fixedld: 12345

Mar1 Sept1 Dec 31

ub-object: Vehicle, f
Policy Change \ Kub-object: =|

Color: BLUE

\| EffectiveDate: Sep 1
ExpirationDate: null
Fixedld: 12345

Window mode and slice mode overview

i Two modes to access a branch’s objects Gi

¢ Usually, jobs change policy data across effective time
* Slice mode is viewing policy data as of a specific date in effective time

« When you request objects on the policy in slice mode, PolicyCenter automatically gets the
correct version of each object as of the slice date

¢ Window mode is viewing all versions of policy data across all dates in effective
time
* For example, you want to get all the costs for a vehicle within a policy term (cost may vary if
coverages have changed)

* Or you want to list all the drivers ever assigned to a vehicle (a driver may only be assigned for
short period)

I Example

Effective time

+

Jan1 Apr MayJune Dec 31

04/01: Submission
creates policy
with 1 red car

Model time

05/01: Change
add a blue car 2

06/01: Change
remove car 2

Enforced PolicyPeriod

I Slice mode view as of: G

Effective time

Jan1 Apr MayJune Dec 31
Model time 1
Apr 30? —— Policy has one red car
2

May 30? © © | Mmmm §=Policy has two cars
= MEE §=(one red, one blue)
3

Nov 25? © 0 |

xs ——— Policy has one red car

On any date, you might not see all cars that exist at some point in that policy period

i Window mode view Gi

Effective time

Jan1 Apr MayJune Dec 31
1 2 3
Page a
eS” S32

* Lists all cars that existed on the policy for any period of time with the effective dates
+ First, get a list of all cars that were ever on the policy
+ Next, for each car, you want to iterate across all changes to that car across effective time
* Obtained by using the VersionList property on a policy period
¢ There are two cars in VersionList but there are three versions of the policy
+ Submission, Policy Change 1, Policy Change 2

i Demonstration G

Slice Mode

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

i Slice mode API: getSlice(sliceDate)

¢ Access a slice from a PolicyPeriod

* Syntax: slicedPolicyPeriod = aBranch.getSlice(sliceDate)
+ Return value is in slice mode
« Returns sliced PolicyPeriod
* Displays view of PolicyPeriod as of slice date

Example: getSlice using Gosu Tester and verified using date Gi
selector in the Ul

®)Gosu Scratchpad

>& ¥ 8
uses java.text.SimpleDateFormat
var branch = Job. finder. findJobByJobNumber ("47586734721") .LatestPeriod
var dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat ("M/dd/yyyy")

var i=;

for (v in sliceView.PersonalAutoLine.Vehicles) {
print ("Vehicle "+i +"

" + v.DisplayName)

[eppolicy File @> Personal auto Ray Newton )
. Debug "= server
Vehicles G | Debugger] Eel console =
Vehicle Details Vehicle 1: 2001 Acura RSX in California
Wehicle 2: 2002 Toyota Avalon in California
Vehicle # Vehicle Type Modelvear |/aake =” Model > | Body Type

2 Passenger/Light Truck 2002 Toyota Avalon

Vehicle Details | Additional interest

Basic Vehicle Information

fehicle = 1

i Window mode API: VersionList Gi

¢ Version list represents all versions of an object in a policy period across effective
time
« Use any object’s VersionList property to get a version list
* versionList.AllVersions property gets all versions of this object
* Sorted on effective date for each version

* versionList.AsOf(date) method gets the one version of this object on that date, or
null if none were effective on that date

i Version list examples Gi

¢ Get all versions of a particular car in a policy period across effective time :
* var val = vehicleVL.AllVersions

+ Ifthe car was added and then removed in a subsequent change transaction (as discussed previously),
the car would still be listed

+ It existed on the policy period at some point
* Get the car version that is effective on ‘date’
* var vehOnDate = vehicleVL.AsOf(date)
« Returns
+ Single car object in window mode

+ Null if no version of the car is effective at that date

i VersionList examples: Get vehicles on a policy

¢ All versions of all vehicles that ever existed on the Policy
Gosu Source

var branch = Job. finder. findJobByJobNumber (“206921”). LatestPeriod
branch. PersonalautoLine.VersionList.Vehicles.flatMap(A vl + vl.AllVersions).each(A v > print(v))

Runtime Output

¢ All vehicles as of specific date
Gosu Source

var branch = Job. finder. findJobByJobNumber (“206921” ). LatestPeriod
branch. PersonalAutoLine. VersionList. VehiclesAs0f ("2012-06-02").each(A v + print(v))

Runtime Output

VersionList examples: Get costs on a policy

All costs on a personal auto policy

Gosu Source

var branch = Job. finder. findJobByJobNumber (“206921”). LatestPeriod
branch. PersonalautoLine.VersionList. PACosts.flatMap(A cl > cl.AllVersions).each(A c + print(c})

Runtime Output

urban in Calif

J in California

in California

burban in ¢

¢ All costs on a vehicle at a specific date
Gosu Source

var branch = Job. finder. findJobByJobNumber (“206921” ). LatestPeriod
branch. PersonalAutoLine. VersionList. PACostsAs0f ("2012-04-02").each({ Ac > print(c))

They have an effective date and an expiration date.

Window mode and slice mode overview

i Two modes to access a branch’s objects Gi

¢ Usually, jobs change policy data across effective time
* Slice mode is viewing policy data as of a specific date in effective time

« When you request objects on the policy in slice mode, PolicyCenter automatically gets the
correct version of each object as of the slice date

¢ Window mode is viewing all versions of policy data across all dates in effective
time
* For example, you want to get all the costs for a vehicle within a policy term (cost may vary if
coverages have changed)

* Or you want to list all the drivers ever assigned to a vehicle (a driver may only be assigned for
short period)

I Example

Effective time

+

creates policy
with 1 red car

Model time

05/01: Change
add a blue car 2

i Window mode API: VersionList Gi

¢ Version list represents all versions of an object in a policy period across effective
time
« Use any object’s VersionList property to get a version list
* versionList.AllVersions property gets all versions of this object
* Sorted on effective date for each version

* versionList.AsOf(date) method gets the one version of this object on that date, or
null if none were effective on that date

i Version list examples Gi

¢ Get all versions of a particular car in a policy period across effective time :
* var val = vehicleVL.AllVersions

+ Ifthe car was added and then removed in a subsequent change transaction (as discussed previously),
the car would still be listed

+ It existed on the policy period at some point
* Get the car version that is effective on ‘date’
* var vehOnDate = vehicleVL.AsOf(date)
« Returns
+ Single car object in window mode

+ Null if no version of the car is effective at that date

¢ All versions of all vehicles that ever existed on the Policy
